Learn More & Join Download Assignment PDF Before You Shoot â€¢ Choose a subject that can benefit from either shallow or deep depth of field. â€¢ Select a location with varied backgrounds to test depth of field effects. â€¢ Ensure your camera is set to Aperture Priority mode (A/Av) or Shutter Priority mode (S/Tv). â€¢ Set your ISO to a fixed value of 200. â€¢ Bring a tripod for stable shots when using slower shutter speeds. The Assignment Technical Focus â€¢ Use a wide aperture (e.g., f/2.8) to create shallow depth of field for portraits. â€¢ Utilize a narrow aperture (e.g., f/16) for landscapes to achieve maximum sharpness. â€¢ Experiment with different focal lengths to see how they affect depth of field. â€¢ Focus on the nearest eye when capturing portraits to ensure sharpness. â€¢ For landscapes, focus slightly beyond the nearest detail for optimal depth. Creative Focus â€¢ Try to tell a story through selective focus by isolating key elements in your composition. â€¢ Incorporate foreground elements to enhance depth when using shallow depth of field. â€¢ Vary your angles and perspectives to see how they influence depth of field. â€¢ Create a series of images with varying depth of field for a cohesive narrative. â€¢ Use depth of field to guide the viewer's eye towards the main subject. Assignment Tasks â€¢ Use aperture priority mode at f/2.8 with ISO 200 fixed to photograph a portrait, focusing on the subject's eyes while blurring the background. â€¢ Set your camera to aperture priority mode at f/16 with ISO 200 fixed and capture a landscape scene to achieve sharpness from foreground to background. â€¢ Experiment with different focal lengths by taking the same portrait at f/2.8 and f/4 while changing your distance from the subject. â€¢ Use shutter priority mode at 1/500s with ISO 200 fixed to capture a moving subject, allowing the camera to set the aperture for optimal depth of field. â€¢ Shoot a close-up of a flower using aperture priority mode at f/4 with ISO 200 fixed, ensuring the background is softly blurred. â€¢ Capture an image of a street scene at f/8 with ISO 200 fixed, allowing the camera to adjust shutter speed for a balanced exposure. ðŸ’¡ Stretch Tasks â€¢ Create a diptych showcasing the same scene with both shallow and deep depth of field effects, using aperture priority mode for both. â€¢ Challenge yourself to use hyperfocal distance principles in a landscape shot by setting your aperture to f/11 with ISO 200 fixed. DO / DON'T DO â€¢ âœ“ Do experiment with different aperture settings to see their effects on depth of field. â€¢ âœ“ Do focus on the most important element in your composition to ensure it remains sharp. â€¢ âœ“ Do use a tripod for landscape shots to avoid camera shake at slower shutter speeds. â€¢ âœ“ Do review your images to analyze how different depths of field affect your storytelling. â€¢ âœ“ Do practice switching between aperture and shutter priority modes to see how they influence your creative choices. DON'T â€¢ âœ— Don't use manual mode with all settings specified; focus on priority modes instead. â€¢ âœ— Don't forget to check your background for distractions that may affect your depth of field. â€¢ âœ— Don't assume that shallow depth of field is always better; consider the context of your subject. â€¢ âœ— Don't rush your shots; take time to compose and adjust settings for optimal results. â€¢ âœ— Don't limit yourself to one type of subject; explore various scenes to understand depth of field.
